facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 136 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 333 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 24, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 333 of 1960.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the petition filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: against its judgment dated February 24, 1961, dismissing the petition filed by the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Appellant carried on business in India and outside India, i.e. Ceylon, the former States of Kolhapur and Kapurthala and other places.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, at the material time, carried on business number only in India but also outside India, i.e. Ceylon, the former States of Kolhapur and Kapurthala and other places.

facts.text: It is common ground that the facts relating to Ceylon income and Kolhapur income are substantially similar.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to give the facts relating to the income in Ceylon and Kolhapur because if the facts relating to the income made in Kapurthala are stated, these will bring out the real companytroversy between the appellant and the Revenue.

facts.text: On July 9, 1954, the appellant wrote a letter to the Income Tax Officer, Companies Circle, Bombay, stating that for the assessment year 1949-50, it was entitled to refund on the income taxed in Kapurthala State.

anchor.surface_text: On July 9, 1954, the appellant wrote a letter to the Income Tax Officer, Companies Circle, Bombay, stating that for the assessment year 1949-50, it was entitled to refund on the income taxed in Kapurthala State.

facts.text: Appellant attached an original certificate for tax showing payment of Rs. 37,828/11/- .

anchor.surface_text: It attached an original certificate for tax showing payment of Rs. 37,828/11/-, and requested that a refund order be passed at an early date.

facts.text: On June 27, 1956, the Income Tax Officer rejected the claim on the ground that the claim filed by the appellant was not within the time limit of four years laid down in r. 5 of Income-Tax Double Taxation Relief (Indian States) Rules 1939.

This appeal raises a short question as to the construction of S. 49E of the Indian IncomeTax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Requires a subsisting obligation to pay the refund before set-off can be claimed; a barred claim under final order does not qualify as 'found to be due' for set-off in lieu of payment.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power to set off amount of refunds against tax remaining payable

anchor.surface_text: Section 49E reads thus 49E. Power to set off amount of refunds against tax remaining payable.Where under any of the provisions of this Act, a refund is found to be due to any person, the Income-tax Officer, Appellant Assistant Commissioner or Commissioner, as the case may be may, in lieu of payment of the refund, set off the amount to be refunded, or any part of that amount against the tax, interest or penalty if any, remaining payable by the person to whom the refund is due.

concepts.interpretation: No prior adjudication necessary but refund must be due with subsisting payment obligation; 'in lieu of payment' implies existing liability to pay.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power to set off amount of refunds against tax remaining payable

anchor.surface_text: But we cannot go into the question whether r. 5 was rightly or wrongly applied by the Income- Tax authorities. The orders dated August 23, 1958

holdings.text: The orders dated August 23, 1958 and December 31, 1958, cannot be attacked in these proceedings. Therefore, we must proceed on the basis that those orders were validly passed.

anchor.surface_text: But we cannot go into the question whether r. 5 was rightly or wrongly applied by the Income- Tax authorities. The orders dated August 23, 1958 and December 31, 1958, cannot be attacked in these proceedings. Therefore, we must proceed on the basis that those orders were validly passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior unchallenged administrative orders of Commissioner and Central Board are final and binding; no collateral attack permitted in subsequent writ proceedings.

holdings.text: It is not necessary that there should be a prior adjudication before a claim can be allowed under s. 49E. There is nothing to debar the Income-Tax Officer from determining the question whether a refund is due or not when an application is made to him under s. 49E.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises as to whether there should be a prior adjudication existing before a set off can be allowed under 49E, and whether there is any other condition which is necessary to be fulfilled before the section becomes applicable. We are of the opinion that it is not necessary that there should be a prior adjudication before a claim can be allowed under s. 49E.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of 'found to be due' does not require prior adjudication; ITO empowered to determine refund due upon application under s.49E.

holdings.text: Section 59(5) provides that the rules made under this section shall have effect as if enacted under this Act. This provision thus makes the Indian State Rules, 1939, part of the Act, and consequently if a refund is due under the Rules, it would be refund due under the Act within the meaning of s. 49E.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.59(5) statutorily incorporates rules into the Act, making refunds under rules equivalent to refunds under the Act for s.49E purposes.

holdings.text: There must be a subsisting obligation to make the payment of refund before a person is entitled to claim a set off under s. 49E.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'In lieu of payment' connotes existing liability to pay refund; final orders barring claim extinguish obligation; analogy to Stubbs v. Director of Public Prosecutions.

holdings.text: S. 49E of the Act is of no assistance to the appellant and that the petition was rightly dismissed by the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.49E interpretation to facts: prior final orders rejecting refund create no subsisting obligation, barring set-off.

anchor.surface_text: But we cannot go into the question whether r. 5 was rightly or wrongly applied by the Income- Tax authorities. The orders dated August 23, 1958 and December 31, 1958, cannot be attacked in these proceedings. Therefore, we must proceed on the basis that those orders were validly passed.
Therefore, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that S. 49E of the Act is of numberassistance to the appellant and that the petition was rightly dismissed by the High Court.

The question then arises as to whether there should be a prior adjudication existing before a set off can be allowed under 49E, and whether there is any other condition which is necessary to be fulfilled before the section becomes applicable. We are of the opinion that it is not necessary that there should be a prior adjudication before a claim can be allowed under s. 49E.
Therefore, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that S. 49E of the Act is of numberassistance to the appellant and that the petition was rightly dismissed by the High Court.
